case_name: Assistant Custodian of Evacuee Property v. Official Receiver

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 489 of 1962 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL, APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 489 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated April 18, 1960, of Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Civil Writ No. 200-D of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 18, 1960, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Civil Writ No. 200-D of 1955.

facts.text: Daulat Ram Surana was an Indian citizen carrying on business at Delhi as a jeweller in the name of Sardar Singh Daulat Ram.

anchor.surface_text: An Indian citizen named Daulat Ram Surana was carrying on business at Delhi as a jeweller in the name of Sardar Singh Daulat Ram.

facts.text: Daulat Ram Surana had a Muslim mistress and migrated to Pakistan in the first week of February 1950.

anchor.surface_text: He had a Muslim mistress and it appears that by reason of Ms affection for the said mistress he migrated to Pakistan in the first week of February, 1950.

facts.text: Daulat Ram Surana transferred his 1/2 share in ancestral house in Baidwara Street, Delhi for Rs. 26,000 before migrating to Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: before he migrated to Pakistan he transferred his I share in his ancestral house in Baidwara Street, Delhi for a companysideration of Rs. 26,000.

facts.text: On March 14, 1950, Nanak Chand and others filed petition of insolvency against the firm of Daulat Ram and Daulat Ram.

anchor.surface_text: On the 14th March, 1950, Nanak Chand and certain other persons claiming to be his creditors, filed a petition of insolvency against the firm of Daulat Ram and against Daulat Ram himself.

facts.text: On June 17, 1950, the firm and Daulat Ram were adjudicated insolvents and Official Receiver appointed receiver of the estate.

anchor.surface_text: On June 17, 1950, both the firm and Daulat Ram were adjudicated insolvents and the respondent, the Official Receiver, was appointed the Receiver of the estate of the insolvents.

facts.text: In August 1951, Official Receiver wanted to sell some items of insolvents' property, sale fixed for August 18, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: In August, 1951, the Official Receiver wanted to sell some items of the insolvents property and the sale was fixed to be held on the 18th August, 1951.

facts.text: Two days prior to August 18, 1951, Assistant Custodian issued notice under s.7(1) of the Act to Daulat Ram and other interested persons.

anchor.surface_text: Two days prior thereto, however,. the Assistant Custodian of Evacuee Property issued a numberice under S. 7 1  of the Act to Daulat Ram and other interested persons to show cause why be should number be declared an evacuee

facts.text: Official Receiver appeared before Assistant Custodian and raised objections to Daulat Ram's property being declared evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent came to know of the said proceedings, appeared before the Assistant Custodian and raised objections to the property of Daulat Ram being declared as evacuee property.

facts.text: Assistant Custodian overruled objections and declared Daulat Ram's property evacuee property on February 15, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: These objections were overruled by the Assistant Custodian and the property of Daulat Ram was declared evacuee property on the 15th February,1954.

facts.text: Official Receiver appealed to Authorised Deputy Custodian, appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent challenged this order by preferring an appeal before the Authorised Dy. Custodian, and when the appeal was dismissed,

facts.text: Official Receiver filed revision to Custodian General, dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: he moved the Custodian General in his revisional jurisdiction. The revision application filed by the respondent was also dismissed.

facts.text: Official Receiver filed writ petition in Punjab High Court, Civil Writ No. 200-D of 1955, challenging orders declaring property evacuee.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then moved the Punjab High Court by a writ petition and challenged the validity of the orders passed by the respective authorities under the Act, declaring the property of Daulat Ram as evacuee property.

facts.text: Deputy Custodian, Authorised Deputy Custodian, and Assistant Custodian impleaded as respondents in writ petition (appellants in SC).

anchor.surface_text: To this petition, the Dy. Custodian, Evacuee Property, the Authorised Dy. Custodian and the Assistant Custodian were impleaded as respondents. These are the appellants before us.

facts.text: Bishan Narain J. referred writ petition to Division Bench due to importance.

anchor.surface_text: When this matter was taken up before Bishan Narain J. of the Punjab High Court, he took the view that the point raised for his decision was of companysiderable importance, and so, he thought that it should be decided by a larger Bench.

facts.text: Division Bench of Punjab High Court quashed orders declaring Daulat Ram's property evacuee property by writ of certiorari.

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench has upheld the plea raised by the respondent and has directed that the orders made by the Custodian Department that the entire property of Daulat Ram vests in the Custodian are illegal and should be quashed by a writ of certiorari.

facts.text: Appellants contend vesting of evacuee property from date of migration, February 7 or 8, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The date of Daulat Rams migration to Pakistan is February 7 or 8, 1950, and the appellants case is that though the declaration that Daulat Rams property is evacuee property was made on February 15, 1954, the vesting must be deemed to have taken place as from February 7 or 8, 1950.

facts.text: Appellants concede insolvency adjudication on June 17, 1950 relates back to March 14, 1950 per s.28(7) Provincial Insolvency Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants companycede that the order of adjudication made against Daulat Ram on the June 17, 1950 would, by virtue of the provisions companytained in s. 28 7  of the Provincial Insolvency Act relate back to the date of the presentation of the petition made by his creditors in that behalf, and that takes us to March 14, 1950.

facts.text: Daulat Ram became an evacuee under s.2(d)(i) of the Act as found by authorities.

anchor.surface_text: It has been found by the appropriate authorities that Daulat Ram became an evacuee under s. 2 d   i  of the Act,

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that for declaration under s.7(1), property must be evacuee property at the date of declaration.

anchor.surface_text: If the view taken by the High Court is right, that before a declaration can be made under s. 7 1 , it must be shown that the property which is the subject-matter of the proceedings under the said provision is, at the date of the declaration, evacuee property,

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside High Court order and dismisses writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside and the writ petition filed by the respondent is dismissed.

in issuing a notification of evacuee property under section 7 1  of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950  No. 31 of 1950   hereinafter called the Act ? That is the short question which arises in this appeal.

issues.text: What is the relevant date by reference to which the character of the property has to be determined in issuing a notification of evacuee property under section 7(1) of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 (No. 31 of 1950) (hereinafter called the Act)?

anchor.surface_text: What is the relevant date by reference to which the character of the property has to be determined in issuing a notification of evacuee property under section 7 1  of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950  No. 31 of 1950   hereinafter called the Act ?

issues.text: Whether the declaration under s.7(1) of the Act prevails over the adjudication under the Provincial Insolvency Act because the retrospective vesting under s.8(1)(a) of the Act dates back to migration prior to the insolvency petition date?

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contend that when a notification is issued under s. 7  1   of the Act, the vesting of the evacuee property in the Custodian takes effect in the present case from the date when the evacuee migrated to Pakistan. The date of Daulat Rams migration to Pakistan is February 7 or 8, 1950,

arguments.claim: High Court's view does not represent true scope of s.7(1); appeal allowed, HC order set aside, writ dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside and the writ petition filed by the respondent is dismissed.

holdings.text: Section 8(1) provides for a statutory consequence of a valid declaration made under s. 7(1) and cannot be pressed into service for construing s. 7(1).

anchor.surface_text: Section 8 l  can come into operation only if and after a notification has been validly and properly made under s. 7 1 . In other words, s. 8 1  provides for a statutory consequence of a valid declaration made under s. 7 1 . That is why the said section cannot be pressed into service for construing s. 7  1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.8 operates only after valid s.7 declaration; using it to interpret s.7 would circularly assume validity of declaration it presupposes.

holdings.text: There is no inconsistency between the relevant provisions of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act and the Provincial Insolvency Act, so s.4(1) does not apply to make the former prevail.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant provisions of the two sections of the Provincial Insolvency Act do not disclose anything inconsistent with the relevant provisions of the Act, and so, there is no occasion to invoke the provisions of s. 4  1 in order to establish the conclusion that the provisions of the Act will prevail over the said provisions of the Insolvency Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Insolvency ss.27/28(7) merely vest property from petition date upon adjudication; no conflict with Evacuee Act ss.7/8 vesting.

holdings.text: The decision in Ebrahim Aboobaker's case has no relevance to construing s.7(1) here, as the evacuee was alive during the inquiry and there was no infirmity in proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: With respect, we are unable to see how the decision of this Court in Ebrahim Aboobakers case 1 can have any relevance or materiality in construing S. 7 1 of the Act for the purpose of deciding the dispute between the parties before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ebrahim turned on inability to inquire after death of alleged evacuee; distinguished as evacuee alive and inquiry valid.

holdings.text: s.7(1) must be construed by liberal/purposive construction considering context, other provisions, and Act's object, not merely grammatical rules.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the construction of s. 7 1 presents a problem which can be resolved not merely by the adoption of the mechanical rule of construction based on grammar, but by a liberal construction which takes into account the bearing and purport of the relevant words used in s. 7 1 ,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal reading leads to anomalies (e.g., post-migration transfers escape Act); purposive reading aligns with ss.2(f),40,7(1A),7(2) and economic protection object.

holdings.text: The legislature did not intend to permit transfers by evacuees between migration and s.7(1) proceedings to escape the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, it is very difficult, if not impossible, to assume that such could have been the intention of the legislature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Such transfers would defeat Act's purpose like pre-migration (s.40) or pending proceedings (s.7(2)); consistent scheme catches all evacuee-linked property.

holdings.text: The High Court's view does not correctly represent the true scope and effect of s.7(1).

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that the view taken by the High Court does not correctly represent the true scope and effect of the provisions contained in S.7 1 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of purposive construction, avoidance of anomalies, legislative scheme, and object overrides literal interpretation adopted by HC.

holdings.text: Daulat Ram became an evacuee under s.2(d)(i) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It has been found by the appropriate authorities that Daulat Ram became an evacuee under s. 2 d   i  of the Act,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts findings of custodian authorities below.

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed, the High Court order is set aside, and the writ petition is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside and the writ petition filed by the respondent is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Custodian declaration under s.7(1) valid; vesting under s.8(1)(a) retrospective to migration date prevails over later insolvency vesting.

precedents.case_name: Ebrahim Aboobaker and Anr. Tek Chand Dolwani
precedents.cited_proposition: Proceedings under S. 7(1) of the Act terminate on the death of the alleged evacuee as the property vests in heirs and cannot be declared evacuee property after death
precedents.cited_holding: where a Mohammedan against whom proceedings are commenced under the Act for declaring him an evacuee and his properties evacuee properties, dies during the pendency of the proceedings, he cannot be declared an evacuee after his death, and his properties which on his death vest in his heirs under the Mohammedan law cannot be declared evacuee properties

precedents.cited_proposition: principles laid down that proceedings under S. 7(1) cannot be instituted after death of alleged evacuee
decision in which proceedings under S. 7(1) held to have no relevance to construction in insolvency context

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; respondent's writ petition dismissed.
